channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Lede: A Twitter Message About AIDS, Africa and Race
item.description: A message from the Twitter account of Justine Sacco, InterActiveCorp’s public relations director, was criticized as being in questionable taste.
item.dc:creator: By ASHLEY SOUTHALL
item.media:description: A screen grab of @justinesacco's tweets before the account was removed.

item.title: The Lede: Statement From Khodorkovsky in Berlin Answers Some Questions, but Not All
item.description: Hours after his sudden release from prison on Friday, the Russian dissident Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky released a statement from Berlin, along with an image of himself free for the first time in 10 years.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: Mikhail Khodorkovsky, at left, shaking hands with the former German foreign minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, at the airport in Berlin on Friday.

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Woman Who Sought Assisted Suicide Dies
item.description: The partner of a paralyzed woman who lost a highly publicized court battle in Ireland to let him help her commit suicide said Friday that she had died.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Judge Rejects Libyan’s Rendition Case
item.description: A Libyan dissident, Abdel Hakim Belhaj, cannot pursue in a British court his “well founded” claim that he was unlawfully abducted in 2004, and later tortured.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Despite Baucus Nomination, Critics Cite Void in China Lineup
item.description: After Senator Max Baucus was appointed ambassador to China, questions have arisen as to who, other than President Obama himself, will have an influential voice in dealing with Beijing.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: Senator Max Baucus, pictured in October, was formally nominated on Friday to be President Obama’s ambassador to China.

item.title: Senate Bill Threatens Nuclear Deal, Analysts Say
item.description: Legislation that threatens Iran with tough sanctions if a deal is not reached on its nuclear program could undermine President Hassan Rouhani, political analysts contend.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: China Revives Mao-Era Self-Criticism, but This Kind Bruises Few Egos
item.description: President Xi Jinping of China has resurrected “criticism and self-criticism” sessions to rally the Communist Party and the public, but the process has been criticized as superficial and just for show.
item.dc:creator: By DAN LEVIN
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping backs criticism sessions as a “powerful weapon.”

item.title: Fragile Lull Is Shattered by Clashes in Africa
item.description: Violence broke out in several quarters of the Central African Republic capital, leaving 19 people dead and breaking the tentative lull that had held for a week.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:description: Smoke rises from a neighborhood in Bangui damaged in sectarian attacks on Friday.

item.title: Canadian Court Strikes Down Laws on Sex Trade
item.description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously that three laws violated prostitutes’ constitutional right to “security of the person.”
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN
item.media:credit: Adrian Wyld/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Valerie Scott, a former prostitute from Toronto, displayed the Canadian Supreme Court ruling on Friday. The court heard her appeal in the case.

item.title: Libya Militias Fleeing Cities, Leaving Chaos
item.description: Civilian protesters and armed groups have chased militias from Tripoli and Benghazi for the first time since the ouster of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in 2011.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Demonstrators last month protested against militias and welcomed the Libyan Army to Benghazi, which has been hit with a series of assassinations and bombings.

item.title: Freed Abruptly by Putin, Khodorkovsky Arrives in Germany
item.description: Mikhail Khodorkovsky, once Russia’s richest man, flew to Berlin on a private jet after President Vladimir V. Putin signed a decree pardoning him early Friday.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.media:description: Mikhail Khodorkovsky, left, with Hans-Dietrich Genscher, after arriving in Berlin from a penal colony in Russia on Friday.

item.title: Contracting Overhaul Is Promised for Navy
item.description: As allegations of overbilling for supplies expand, Navy Secretary Ray Mabus said he had ordered a team of officials to come up with changes to make the Navy less vulnerable to fraud.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTOPHER DREW and DANIELLE IVORY

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Bill Aims to Restrict Abortion
item.description: Spain’s conservative government moved to tighten restrictions on abortion as the cabinet approved a bill that would allow the practice only in certain cases.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Corruption Investigation in Turkey Produces First Arrests
item.description: A corruption investigation that is encircling the government of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan gained momentum on Friday with the first formal arrests. The government responded by dismissing 14 high-ranking police officials.
item.dc:creator: By CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Tibetan Sets Himself on Fire
item.description: A monk in a Tibetan region of western China died after setting fire to himself on Thursday afternoon, according to two Tibet advocacy groups based outside China.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Palestinian Killed Near Border
item.description: Israeli forces fatally shot a Palestinian man who approached the border fence separating Gaza from Israel and wounded five others at several points along the fence, Palestinian medical officials said.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Leading the Charge Against Spain’s Mortgage Crisis
item.description: Ada Colau’s group, the Platform for People Affected by Mortgages, has blocked hundreds of evictions and pressed for changes in Spain’s hard-line mortgage laws.
item.dc:creator: By SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: "We have not changed the law yet. But there is progress. The banks are talking to people now, and they were not before."

item.title: South Sudan Steps Closer to Unraveling
item.description: The United Nations gave details of the deadly assault on a peacekeeping base in South Sudan, where strife between Dinka and Nuer antagonists is rising.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: As fighting has spread, 35,000 to 40,000 civilians, including from Juba, the capital, have taken refuge at other United Nations peacekeeping bases.

item.title: Daughter Seeks Freedom for Jailed Ukraine Leader
item.description: The daughter of former Prime Minister Yulia V. Tymoshenko is seeking freedom for her mother and seeing an example in the release of Russia’s best-known political prisoner.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE and ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Evgenia Tymoshenko, daughter of former Prime Minister Yulia A. Tymoshenko, in Independence Square in Kiev, Ukraine .

item.title: Air Force Removed General Over Drunken Acts in Russia
item.description: After drinking for hours in bars, Maj. Gen. Michael J. Carey was slurring his speech and stumbling through Red Square, and he tried to force a bar band to let him play, according to a report.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER
item.media:credit: U.S. Air Force, via Associated Press

item.title: Yemen Deaths Test Claims of New Drone Policy
item.description: The reported deaths of innocent people in a wedding procession this month illuminated the reality behind the rhetoric of the Obama administration’s new drone policy.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI and ROBERT F. WORTH
item.media:description: A mural depicting an American drone in Sana, Yemen’s capital. A strike last week on a wedding convoy killed at least 12 people.

item.title: South Africa’s Biggest Trade Union Pulls Its Support for A.N.C.
item.description: The move is likely to erode the dominance of the African National Congress ahead of elections and reorder the politics of a country it has governed with huge majorities since the end of white rule.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN

item.title: Drive for Syrian Peace Talks Resumes in Geneva
item.description: Syria’s government and opposition have committed to take part, but Iran’s participation remains blocked by the United States, said the United Nations special envoy for Syria.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: Lakhdar Brahimi, the United Nations special envoy, speaking with members of a French delegation in Geneva on Friday.

item.title: N.S.A. Spied on Allies, Aid Groups and Businesses
item.description: Secret documents reveal more than 1,000 targets of U.S. and British surveillance in recent years, including the office of an Israeli prime minister and heads of international aid organizations.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES GLANZ and ANDREW W. LEHREN
item.media:description: Satellite dishes in Cornwall, England, at an outpost of Britain’s General Communications Headquarters. The agency has worked closely with the United States.

item.title: The Caucus: Highlights From Obama’s News Conference
item.description: President Obama spoke about the N.S.A., health law signups and the ambitions of his second term.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: President Obama arrived in the White House briefing room on Friday for his year-end news conference.
